awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Micro-structure and Electrical Properties in Thin Films of Semicrystalline Conjugated Polymers
awd_abstract_narration:
Technical: This project addresses the micro-structure and electrical properties in thin films of semicrystalline conjugated polymers with emphasis on understanding structure/transport relationships; the micro-structure includes crystalline grains, grain boundaries and amorphous material. The project will utilize poly(thiophenes) and poly(thieno-thiophenes), considered as high-performance polymeric semiconductors. The approach parallels that used with heteroepitaxy and graphoepitaxy to achieve long-range order. Scanning probe techniques, high resolution synchrotron-based X-ray diffraction, and in situ thermal annealing studies will be conducted along with molecular dynamics (MD) simulations of micro-structure evolution. Coupled electrical and optical characterization to separate the effect of different aspects of the micro-structure on the materials' performance will be carried out, and experimental measurements will be augmented by modeling of charge transport. The density-of-states of the semiconductor will be characterized with sub-bandgap absorption spectroscopies. 
Non-technical: The project addresses basic research issues in a topical area of materials science having high technological relevance. The project provides unique opportunities for graduate and undergraduate training in an interdisciplinary field. In addition to Stanford undergraduates, the PI will work pro-actively to attract underrepresented minority students to his laboratory through an Engineering Diversity Program (EDP). The research will also be used as a vehicle to "re-excite" local high-school Science teachers participating in an outreach program. The PI plans to lecture at local high schools and participate in national outreach days organized by EDP.

Organic semiconductors may help fulfill the promise of introducing low-cost, printed electronic devices everywhere. While organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs) have already entered the marketplace, future waves of organic devices may include photovoltaics, tags, sensors as well as the logic circuits needed for integration. In spite of many advances in materials design and device development, the limits of organic semiconductors and what they can achieve are still unknown. Our work has focused on understanding what limits organic semiconductors: knowing the limits will help design new materials to go beyond current performance.

In particular, we have focused on defects that reduce the speed at which charges can move through these materials. The faster the transport of charge in the semiconductor, the faster the switching speed of the devices made with these materials. Hence studying the limits of charge transport is of fundamental importance for the application of organic semiconductors.

By aligning polymer molecules on a surface with a technique called directional crystallization (Figure 1), we were able to show that polymer chains are able to form bridges between polymer crystals. Such bridges facilitate charge transport. This work proves that having longer-chain polymer molecules is clearly important for increasing carrier mobility in the semiconductor. Longer chains however tend to stay disordered and have difficulty crystallizing in ordered structures. Hence there is a trade-off between the necessity to form crystalline regions where charge can move freely (easier with shorter chains), and bridging such regions with polymer molecules (easier with longer chains). As a result, we decided to study how polymer structure affects the order in the crystalline regions, in an effort to determine how much disorder can be tolerated without affecting carrier mobility excessively. In order to do so, we developed a novel measurement protocol based on high-brightness synchrotron radiation in the X-ray region of the electromagnetic spectrum. Thanks to these advanced characterization methods we were able to show that polymer crystals can be very disordered in the direction that is most important when charges need to hop from one molecule to its neighbor. Electronically, this disorder translates in the formation of electronic trap states that hinder the ability of charge to move in the semiconductor. This result is generally valid for all polymers and is therefore of great interest to the community.

Because semiconducting polymers form such disordered crystals, we turned our attention to smaller molecules that are designed to crystallize and therefore exhibit high carrier mobility. In this materials family, charge transport is not limited by the disorder within the crystals but rather by the fact that charge must be able to travel from one crystal grain to the next through a defect-rich region, the grain-boundary. We developed a technique to fabricate well-defined grain-boundaries in a small-molecule organic semiconductor film. Using these “engineered” microstructures (Figure 2), we were able to show that the molecular structure at the grain-boundary plays a crucial role in determining how detrimental it is for charge transport. For the same material, the effect of grain-boundary structure can cause the mobility to vary by two orders of magnitude depending on the relative orientation of the molecules.

While I highlighted here three results that I consider to be the most important ones, this NSF CAREER Award allowed us to publish a total of 17 manuscripts. This body of work substantially advances our knowledge of the relationship between molecular structure and microstructure of organic semiconductors and their ability to transport charge in electronic devices.
